label: 133. Aunt to James B. Heyward -- January 16, 1852
description: Letter from Aunt Smith to James B. Heyward telling him about a new missionary that may be able to administer his joint properties in absence of any other missions.  2p. January 16, 1852.

metadata.label: Description
metadata.value: Letter from Aunt Smith to James B. Heyward telling him about a new missionary that may be able to administer his joint properties in absence of any other missions.  2p. January 16, 1852.

metadata.label: Copyright Status Statement

metadata.label: Transcript
metadata.value: Blue [House?] Jan 16. 1852  I am sure my dear James will say well what has my old Aunt to say now for she is so poor a scribe that she now writes for nothing- well it is true but this time I write I trust for a great deal-I do not mistrust your expression one day at your Plantation three years ago- "When I have my property I will certainly write a [missive?] to preach to and instruct my people" but I know in the multiplicity of worldly concerns Christians even forget Spiritual ones and purposes you have not settled the worldly sufficiently to have attended to the other-I therefore write to let you know that an Episcopal Missionary by the name of Kennerly is settling this side of the River is very much esteemed as a Missionary on slight acquaintance to be sure and has not a great deal to do and therefore can do more for your joint property than many others could and as no Mission I understand has heretofore been established there can do better than at another place-If you choose to write to your Uncle Smith he can engage him for you or you can write to him or your [?] or perhaps at this settling time one or other of you  [End Page 1] will be oftener there and can better see after it yourselves- as Nat has always had one and Wm Henry is a religious Man I presume there will be no difficulty in the way. I felt quite jealous when I heard your name was in the Papers to think I was not to see you but could not hear of you, and therefore perhaps you did not even know we were here or other matters took you up all I can say is I hope to see some or all of you during our stay which I fear will be until pretty late in February I direct this to Blue House presuming you are by this time settled there for the winter- I don't know how to think I may pay you a visit but I hope your long promised visit will be paid us this April as our new child and Nurse will not be at all amiss- We are quite well and hope you are all the same- Mr S writes in much love to all with you at your Uncle Charles and Nat   Yr Affc. Aunt M Smith [End Page 2]
